awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Testing a unified theory of perception and memory in the medial temporal lobe
awd_abstract_narration:
Memory is critical to our everyday existence, enabling us to recognize an acquaintance's face, remember where we have parked our car, or recall an event from last week in vivid detail. And yet, it is fragile: memory performance can decline noticeably with age and deteriorates even more dramatically in individuals with damage to the medial temporal lobes of the brain. Until recently, theories of memory assumed that the medial temporal lobes are dedicated solely to memory function. However, recent evidence suggests that these brain regions are important for other cognitive tasks, including imagining the future and visually discriminating between two highly similar objects. Therefore, a critical gap in current knowledge is a theory of how memory interacts with high-level visual perception and why both of these cognitive functions depend upon the medial temporal lobes. With the support of this NSF CAREER award, Dr. Rosie Cowell will develop such a theory and test it with empirical studies. By applying the theory to both amnesia caused by brain damage and the more moderate memory loss caused by normal aging, this project will investigate whether these two forms of memory loss can be explained by the same mechanisms. In addition, the project will benefit society more broadly by (1) providing a uniquely integrated research training regime in which graduate students receive direct experience with both theory-building and hypothesis-testing, and (2) broadening participation in STEM fields via hands-on science workshops for female students from high-schools that serve under-represented groups, and via public outreach in the local Massachusetts community.

To develop a unifying theory of memory and high-level perception, the proposed research will employ behavioral studies, functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and computational modeling. The studies will examine the effect of perceptual interference on memory in two cognitively-impaired populations: individuals with medial temporal lobe (MTL) damage and heathy, older adults. The central hypothesis of this proposal is that the MTL houses conjunctive representations of objects and events that are critical for both memory and perception. The conjunctions are critical for perception because they allow differentiation between two similar objects or events, and critical for memory because they shield against a constant stream of perceptual interference that would otherwise cause dramatic forgetting of an object or event. It is assumed that both MTL damage and normal aging compromise the conjunctive representations, forcing a person to rely upon the fragmental, feature-based representations that remain in sensory cortex. Feature-based representations are inadequate for differentiating similar items (leading to perceptual impairments) and highly susceptible to perceptual interference (leading to memory problems). The planned studies are expected to reveal that MTL structures contribute to any cognitive task, mnemonic or perceptual, whenever the task solution requires complex, conjunctive representations of stimuli. This representational approach to understanding cognition will be fully exploited by developing a formal, neuro-computationally plausible model that links neural representations to cognitive performance with an explicit mechanism.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: This project has provided new insights into how the human brain achieves visual perception and long-term memory. Specifically, the funded research has developed a theory of high-level visual perception (e.g., identifying and discriminating objects and faces) and long-term, declarative memory (e.g., recognition memory for scenes and objects, or episodic memory for personal life events) that unifies these two domains by explaining findings from both. For decades, the dominant view within cognitive neuroscience was that distinct brain regions underpin different cognitive functions, with long-term, declarative memory supported by the hippocampus and visual perception by the ventral visual pathway. More recently, a growing body of research has refuted that assumption by demonstrating that visual perception and memory are supported by common neural substrates under some circumstances. The work in this project has expanded that body of evidence and, importantly, has fleshed out specific, mechanistic hypotheses about memory, vision and their interaction in the brain.

For example, we have found evidence that the encoding and retrieval processes underpinning long-term, declarative memory, which were widely thought to be tied uniquely to the hippocampus, can unfold in brain regions traditionally thought dedicated to visual processing. In one study, we used functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to examine "recollection" - a memory retrieval process known to be engaged for episodic memory and thought to occur exclusively in the hippocampus. We showed that recollection can rely on extra-hippocampal brain regions including visual cortex, without engaging the hippocampus, when the content of the to-be-retrieved memory is restricted to visual, non-associative (i.e., non-episodic) information. In another study we induced visual learning without awareness, and showed that people can rapidly learn low-level, visual associations between different parts of an object image, without tapping into higher-level knowledge of the object?s identity. This finding is significant because such rapid, associative learning has traditionally been thought reserved for the high-level, arbitrary relations comprising episodic memories (e.g., your memory of the location, guests and cake at your sister's wedding). The finding that such learning can occur for part-to-part visual associations within an object establishes that common learning mechanisms may be shared by visual object processing and episodic memory. Together, these findings suggest that "mnemonic" processes can unfold in "visual" brain regions. This refutes the traditional notion that cognitive function is anatomically segregated in the brain and suggests that the brain regions underpinning vision and memory differ principally in terms of the type of information they contain, rather than the type of cognitive operation they compute.

In further studies we fleshed out the theory of memory and visual perception mechanistically, building a computational model that explains both deficits in visual perception in human amnesic patients and deficits in recognition memory in animals with similar brain damage, using a common mechanism. We also expanded the scope of the theory by applying it to the effects of aging on cognition, where it made accurate predictions for the effects of interference on recognition memory in older adults.

Other studies under this project have established new methodological tools for investigating vision and memory, including: a novel fMRI method for measuring the type of neural code employed by visual cortex; a new and improved Bayesian approach to popular "state trace" analyses of behavioral data; and a novel set of empirically-collected visual and semantic similarity ratings for a collection of visual stimuli (photographs of objects and scenes), which we make available for use by any cognitive researcher requiring a well-parameterized set of visual stimuli.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts goals of this award were: 1) to provide an interdisciplinary training program involving both theory-building and a wide array of experimental techniques; 2) to broaden participation in computational cognitive neuroscience research by mentoring female and under-represented minority (URM) students; and 3) to broaden participation in STEM more generally through public outreach. This award funded the training of 2 postdocs (1 female), 4 graduate students (3 female; 2 URM), 5 undergraduate students conducting independent summer work (5 female; 2 first-generation), and many undergraduates involved in research during the academic year. Graduate students received interdisciplinary training in multiple techniques including connectionist modeling, Bayesian modeling, behavioral studies, fMRI studies (including computationally intensive analyses) and studies of cognitive aging. The award further supported the training of seven "STEM ambassadors" - undergraduates with first-generation or URM status who were provided with a closely-mentored introduction to lab research. The PI and trainees together participated in many outreach activities including Eureka! (an on-campus summer STEM training program for high-school girls from under-served communities), the UMass Advancing Diversity in Research and Practice program, outreach presentations to local senior centers and the UMass Fine Arts Center, and the UMass Amherst Prison Education Initiative, of which the PI is a founding member.
